use_case: Food Market Integration and Value Chain Development
project: Additional Financing to West Africa Food Systems Resilience Program, Phase 1
description: This use case example emphasizes the importance of integrating regional food markets and developing strategic value chains for enhancing food security. The project built upon activities from the parent initiative by disseminating market information and investing in market infrastructure. An innovative strategy was to extend the project’s reach beyond the originally targeted value chains (poultry, rice, and soybeans) to include vegetables, cowpeas, and roots and tubers, which are crucial for local nutrition and livelihoods. The activities aimed to facilitate trade across key corridors and consolidate the food reserve system. This involved scaling up support for the dissemination of market information to help farmers access local, regional, and international markets, and establishing productive alliances between producers and aggregators for better commercialization of agricultural products. Additionally, the project aimed to enhance storage infrastructure and adopt post-harvest processing technologies through matching grants. The focus on promoting standards for quality and packaging aimed to meet market demands, benefiting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), women and youth-led producer groups, and cooperatives within the targeted value chains.
implementer: Ministry of Agriculture - Niger, Ministry of Agriculture, Hydro-Agricultural Developments and Mechanization  - Burkina Faso, Ministry of Rural Development - Mali, Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Rural Development - Togo

project: Strengthening the Partial Credit Guarantee (PCG) Fund for small farmers in Ukraine (Strengthening the PCGF in Agriculture Project)
description: This use case example illustrates the efforts to financial support small farmers in Ukraine through the capitalization of the PCGF (Partial Credit Guarantee Fund). In the context of land reforms and the challenges imposed by war, the PCGF was established to provide partial credit guarantees to small farmers, enabling them to access financing. The project comprised a central component focused on injecting EUR 10 million into PCGF, aiming at fortifying its capacity to support credit-constrained farmers, hence enhancing long-term agricultural development and food security. The fund was planned to be disbursed in two tranches: the first, EUR 6 million, ensuring the PCGF reaches its legally foreseen capital, and the second, EUR 4 million, to be released once the PCGF is fully operational with an acceptable institutional framework. This financial model was developed as part of a broader effort not only to support Ukraine's agricultural sector amid ongoing conflict but also to bolster the framework for sustainable rural development by leveraging private capital.
implementer: Ministry of Agrarian Policy and Food, Partial Credit Guarantee Fund

project: Additional Financing to the Food System Resilience Program, Phase 2 Sierra Leone
description: This use case example details the enhancement of agricultural extension services through technological innovations and digital platforms. In the context of the Food System Resilience Program in Sierra Leone, the project aimed to improve productivity and resilience among farmers by modernizing the delivery of advisory and extension services. The approach involved a comprehensive review and strengthening of the existing agricultural extension system, incorporating digital solutions and private sector engagement to extend reach and efficiency. Key activities included the deployment of digital platforms for service delivery, training and equipping extension staff with digital tools, and fostering private sector involvement in the newly launched electronic extension system. This multifaceted strategy aimed to bolster the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security, ensuring scalable and sustainable impact on the nation's food system by reaching farmers more effectively with vital information and resources.

project: Additional Financing to the Food System Resilience Program, Phase 2 Sierra Leone
description: This use case example focuses on Strengthening Regional Food Security through Integrated Landscape Management (ILM) as a part of Sierra Leone's Food System Resilience Program. In the context of addressing food insecurity and enhancing resilience to climate variability, the project scaled up interventions promoting climate-smart and nutrition-sensitive agricultural practices. The strategy encompassed developing ILM technologies for communal lands to bolster the natural resource base sustainably, alongside promoting nutrition-sensitive practices among vulnerable groups. Activities included training for the establishment of homestead and community vegetable gardens, support for women's groups in establishing horticulture value chains, and capacity building within relevant institutions. This comprehensive approach aimed at not only expanding the supply of nutritious food but also increasing dietary diversity and improving overall food security in the region.
implementer: Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry - Sierra Leone, Ministry of Agricultural Development - Chad, Ministry of Food and Agriculture - Ghana

project: Chad Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Additional Financing
description: This use case example focuses on the effective prevention, detection, and response to COVID-19, enhancing Chad's healthcare system's preparedness. In the context of Chad's healthcare challenges and the global pandemic's impact, the project team implemented a multi-faceted approach towards health emergency preparedness and response. The project comprised several components aiming at not only immediate COVID-19 response but also building a robust system for future potential health emergencies. The first component prioritized enhancing Chad's capabilities to prevent, detect, and efficiently respond to COVID-19 outbreaks. This involved implementing emergency preparedness measures, improving healthcare facilities, and ensuring the availability of medical supplies and equipment necessary for dealing with COVID-19 cases. Recognizing the importance of community involvement in combating the pandemic, the second component emphasized community engagement and the promotion of social and behavioral changes. This part of the project focused on educating the community about COVID-19 prevention measures, encouraging adherence to health guidelines, and combating misinformation related to the virus. Lastly, the third component centered on bolstering implementation management, monitoring, evaluation, and coordination efforts to ensure the project's effectiveness and sustainability. Through strengthened management and evaluation mechanisms, the project aimed to provide a coherent response to COVID-19 while laying the groundwork for handling future health crises.
implementer: Ministère de la Santé Publique

title: COVID-19 Prevention and Response

project: Chad Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Additional Financing
description: This use case example demonstrates a comprehensive method for engaging communities and promoting behavioral changes essential for controlling the spread of COVID-19 in Chad. In the context of significant challenges posed by the pandemic, coupled with pre-existing gaps in the healthcare system, it was imperative to involve communities directly in the response efforts. The project team initiated a series of targeted interventions focusing on enhancing community engagement and fostering social and behavioral changes conducive to public health safety. Recognizing the power of informed communities in disease prevention and control, a key strategy involved developing and disseminating clear, accurate, and culturally sensitive information about COVID-19 prevention and care. This was complemented by building capacities related to risk communication through training programs for healthcare professionals and community leaders. The project facilitated the creation and support of community platforms dedicated to health awareness-raising activities, including but not limited to COVID-19. It also emphasized the need for accurate information dissemination to counteract misinformation and health-related rumors. Through these concerted efforts, the project aimed to cultivate a well-informed public, capable of making health-conscious decisions, thereby contributing to the broader goal of mitigating the pandemic's impact.

project: Chad Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Additional Financing
description: This use case example highlights a strategic approach to enhancing implementation management, monitoring, evaluation, and coordination for Chad's Health Emergency Preparedness and Response initiative. In the context of Chad's pressing need to fortify its public health infrastructure against COVID-19, amidst existing systemic vulnerabilities, this component of the project was critical. The project team focused on establishing robust mechanisms for project management that ensured coherent, efficient, and transparent implementation of all activities across the components. This entailed the creation of a coordinated framework that fostered collaboration among various stakeholders, including government entities, healthcare providers, and international partners. The strategy also included the development and deployment of monitoring and evaluation tools to assess progress towards set objectives continuously. These tools enabled timely identification of challenges and adjustment of tactics as needed. Furthermore, the component emphasized the importance of continuous learning and adaptation, incorporating lessons learned into ongoing and future health preparedness efforts. By bolstering implementation management and coordination, the project aimed to ensure that efforts to prevent, detect, and respond to COVID-19 were carried out effectively, ultimately contributing to the strengthening of Chad's overall health emergency preparedness capacities.

project: Philippine Rural Development Project Scale-up
description: This use case example describes how the Philippine Rural Development Project (PRDP) successfully strengthened value chain analyses (VCA) and institutionalized their use by Local Government Units (LGUs) across the Philippines. In the context of improving agricultural and fishery enterprises nationwide, the PRDP leveraged VCAs in conjunction with edaphic and climate-based suitability criteria for the Department of Agriculture's LGU planning and investment. This initiative has significantly catalyzed the start-up and expansion of many micro, small, and medium-scale agri-fishery enterprises. Through the use of Provincial Commodity Investment Plans (PCIPs), the project created a planning platform for joint investments between the Department of Agriculture and LGUs, mainstreaming and leveraging support from other government agencies. Despite the achievements, there remains a need for further investments in Farm-to-Market Roads (FMRs) and other rural infrastructure to enhance production areas' connectivity with markets. The project's approach focuses on scaling up through fewer but larger outcome-based programs, emphasizing public good investments such as research and development infrastructure markets, and biosecurity.
implementer: Department of Agriculture

project: Philippine Rural Development Project Scale-up
description: This use case example demonstrates the Philippine Rural Development Project's (PRDP) efforts in enhancing the connectivity of production areas with market centers. Throughout the project's implementation, the PRDP has constructed 324 climate-proof farm-to-market roads (FMRs) totaling 2380 kilometers, alongside 45 bridges and several postharvest facilities meeting climate-proof standards. These infrastructures are pivotal in improving the accessibility of production hubs to markets, thereby fostering economic development in rural areas. The Department of Agriculture (DA) has become the key agency responsible for providing these FMRs and bridges, with effective processes mainstreamed for ensuring their operation and maintenance by Local Government Units (LGUs). These achievements have significantly influenced the design and priorities of the PRDP Scale-Up, aligning with higher-level objectives such as developing a competitive, sustainable, and technology-based agricultural sector. The focus on infrastructure development is also expected to contribute to greater national food security, job creation, increased farmer incomes, and resilience to climate change, among other key actions highlighted in governmental strategic agendas.

project: Lebanon: Green Agri-food transformation for economic recovery (GATE)
description: This use case example demonstrates the approach to enhancing agri-food development by improving rural community infrastructure. In the context of developing countries, one critical aspect of stimulating agricultural productivity and economic growth is the development and modernization of rural infrastructure. The project focused on investments in small community-/farmer-led irrigation developments, rehabilitation of rural feeder roads, local agricultural markets, and optimizing existing wastewater treatment systems for agricultural reuse. By implementing these measures in coordination with the Green Plan, unions of municipalities, and the Ministry of Agriculture, the project aimed to support agricultural activities effectively. Operation and maintenance of these infrastructures were ensured through collaborative efforts with local governing bodies, highlighting the importance of local ownership and participatory processes in project success. The initiative stood out for its dedication to regionally balanced fund allocations, evaluated through a participatory process against established criteria focusing on poverty impact, level of agricultural activity, climate co-benefits, and sustainable operation commitments.
implementer: Council for Development and Reconstruction

project: Lebanon: Green Agri-food transformation for economic recovery (GATE)
description: This use case example illustrates the effort to restore access to critical agency-managed services and infrastructure crucial for the resilience and competitiveness of agri-food systems. Given the vital role that infrastructure such as irrigation systems, wastewater management, solid waste management, and farmer markets play in the agri-food sector, a strategic approach centered on rehabilitating these assets was adopted. This strategy focused on ensuring basic system functionality while avoiding superfluous complexity in interventions to maximize resource use and minimize implementation risks. To achieve these aims, a framework was established to assess, validate, and prioritize investments based on their contribution to rural areas, alignment with national sectoral strategies, and support from local communities. This method underscores the significance of integrating technical, economic, social, and environmental considerations in revitalizing essential services, emphasizing resilient design and sustainable operation and maintenance plans. Ultimately, this approach fostered inclusivity and stakeholder engagement in revitalizing infrastructure critical for agricultural development.

project: Lebanon: Green Agri-food transformation for economic recovery (GATE)
description: This use case example details the advancement of climate-smart agriculture practices through an improved knowledge base and the incorporation of digital innovations. With agricultural sustainability and productivity heavily dependent on accessing credible and timely information, this component aimed to empower farmers, policymakers, and agribusinesses with the necessary tools for informed decision-making. Investments included diagnostics, productivity maps, digitalization of agricultural services, and capacity-building in remote sensing. A key aspect was offering training on climate-smart practices to thousands of smallholders, demonstrating a large-scale effort to adapt farming practices to the reality of climate change. This initiative not only improved the resourcefulness and resilience of the farming sector but also established a robust framework for the collection and utilization of agronomic data. It reflects the increasing recognition of the digital revolution’s role in transforming agriculture into a more sustainable and productive industry, highlighting the potential for technology to facilitate significant improvements in agricultural practices.

use_case: Strengthening Food Safety for Export Growth
project: Lebanon: Green Agri-food transformation for economic recovery (GATE)
description: This use case example explores how enhancing food safety standards and practices can open up export opportunities and improve public health outcomes. The project aimed to align national food safety requirements with international standards, implement management systems like HACCP, and strengthen the operational capacities of sector institutions. Key activities included harmonizing regulations, digitizing agri-food related licenses, and improving laboratory testing capacities. Additionally, the program supported campaigns for livestock vaccination and pests and disease surveillance, addressing the dual challenges of food safety and climate change-induced risks. This multi-faceted approach not only aimed to increase the safety and quality of food products but also sought to enhance Lebanon’s competitiveness in global markets. By fostering a more standardized and transparent food safety system, the project contributed to better health outcomes for consumers and growth opportunities for producers, showcasing the potential of strategic interventions in bolstering the agri-food sector's international standing and local public health.
implementer: Council for Development and Reconstruction

project: Lebanon: Green Agri-food transformation for economic recovery (GATE)
description: This use case example focuses on boosting agri-food sector export performance through strategic marketing and international trade facilitation. Given the potential of the agri-food sector as a driver of economic growth, the project implemented measures to enhance export capabilities and market access. By co-financing trade missions, facilitating participation in international fairs, and providing technical assistance on export processes and requirements, the initiative sought to better position producers in the global marketplace. In addition to practical support for exporters, efforts to upgrade digital platforms for trade information dissemination underscored the role of technology in modern trade facilitation. This method underscored the importance of equipping producers with the knowledge and resources to navigate complex international trade environments successfully. It illustrates the effectiveness of targeted support and capacity-building in empowering the agricultural sector to reach new markets and contribute more significantly to economic recovery and development.

project: Water Emergency Relief Project
description: This use case example demonstrates the effective provision of emergency water supply to identified rural areas. In the context of a project aimed at improving access to critical water services in Afghanistan, the team placed a significant emphasis on securing an emergency water supply for vulnerable populations. By carefully identifying areas most in need due to the ongoing crisis, the team could prioritize efforts where the impact would be most substantial. The implementation involved a multi-faceted approach that included assessing local water resources, deploying mobile water purification systems, and establishing temporary water distribution points. The ultimate goal was to ensure that communities with the most pressing needs received immediate support, showcasing how targeted interventions can address urgent water scarcity challenges.
implementer: Aga Khan Foundation USA, The United Nations Office for Project Services

project: Water Emergency Relief Project
description: This use case example outlines the enhancement of surface water irrigation in selected rural areas using solar technologies. Within the broader aim to improve water access in Afghanistan, the project team focused on leveraging solar technologies to enhance irrigation systems, thereby supporting agricultural productivity. The context was challenging, necessitating inventive approaches to address water scarcity and reliance on inefficient, traditional irrigation methods. By introducing solar-powered pumps and developing community-operated irrigation schemes, the project significantly reduced water loss, increased agricultural yields, and fostered local engagement in sustainable water management. The success of this initiative demonstrates the viability of solar technologies in transforming irrigation practices in resource-constrained environments, offering a sustainable path toward improved water security and agricultural resilience.

project: Water Emergency Relief Project
description: This use case example highlights the strategic deployment of technical training and public awareness campaigns to foster water literacy. The initiative was part of a comprehensive effort to bolster safe drinking and irrigation water services in Afghanistan’s rural areas. Recognizing the pivotal role of community involvement in sustainable water management, the project team executed a series of educational activities aimed at enhancing understanding of water conservation, hygiene practices, and the operation of newly introduced technologies such as solar-powered irrigation systems. These campaigns were designed to empower communities, particularly women and children, with the knowledge and skills necessary for maintaining improved water services and for advocating water conservation within their communities. The approach illustrates the power of education and community engagement in instilling long-lasting changes in water management practices.

project: Water Emergency Relief Project
description: This use case example showcases the importance of a robust implementation support structure for water projects. Within the framework of addressing emergency water needs and enhancing water services in Afghanistan, the project team established a comprehensive support system that facilitated smooth project execution. This included forming partnerships with local NGOs, leveraging expertise from international organizations, and coordinating with community representatives to ensure alignment with local needs and cultural contexts. The support structure played a critical role in navigating logistical challenges, facilitating technology transfer, and enabling effective communication among stakeholders. By doing so, it ensured the project's adaptability, scalability, and overall success, serving as a testament to the criticality of solid foundations and collaborative efforts in complex humanitarian interventions.

project: Ghana Tree Crop Diversification Project
description: This use case example discusses the strategy implemented to enhance social resilience in Ghana by addressing gender inequities in agriculture. In the context of the Ghanaian agricultural sector, women contribute significantly to labor but face notable disparities in asset ownership, financial access, and representation in farming organizations. The project undertook a multifaceted approach to empower female farmers and participants in the agricultural value chain. It aimed at providing equal access to productive resources, formal financial services, and leadership roles in farmer-based organizations (FBOs). Strategies included ensuring women could own farms at rates closer to their male counterparts, improving women's access to formal financial services, and increasing their representation in both upstream and downstream agricultural activities. By targeting these areas, the project not only sought to close the gender gap but also to improve overall agricultural output and household welfare, taking into account that equipping women with similar resources as men could potentially raise agricultural productivity by up to 30 percent and national agricultural output by 4 percent.
implementer: The Tree Crops Development Authority (TCDA), The Ghana Cocoa Board (COCOBOD)

title: Enhancing Social Resilience

project: Ghana Tree Crop Diversification Project
description: This use case example outlines the project’s focused efforts to narrow the gender gaps in the tree crop sector, thereby aiming for longer-term impacts on women’s incomes and household welfare. In the challenging context of gender disparities in the Ghanaian agriculture sector, this project creatively leverages a combination of strategies to empower women. It does so by enhancing their access to productive resources, financial services, and fostering entrepreneurial capacities. Specific interventions include tailored advice, support in opening bank and mobile money accounts for direct livelihood payments, and encouraging women's participation and leadership in decision-making within the sector. Additionally, the project aligns with the World Bank’s Gender Strategy by aiming to increase job opportunities and control over assets for women. It underscores a commitment to conduct further analysis to dismantle barriers to women’s participation and utilizes a community outreach model to engage women through local groups and stakeholders, thus ensuring a comprehensive and inclusive approach to closing gender gaps.
implementer: The Tree Crops Development Authority (TCDA), The Ghana Cocoa Board (COCOBOD)

use_case: Agricultural Productivity and Livestock Health Enhancement
project: Additional Financing to the  Central African Republic  (CAR) Emergency Food Crisis Response Project
description: This use case example outlines the methodological approach taken in the Central African Republic (CAR) Emergency Food Crisis Response Project to enhance agricultural productivity and livestock health to increase food production and improve the resilience of targeted smallholder farmers and food insecure households. In the context of the CAR, a country grappling with severe food insecurity exacerbated by natural disasters, conflicts, and economic challenges, the project provided a multi-faceted support system aiming at the core of agricultural production. Firstly, it supplied over 329,000 farmers, 51% of whom are women, with vital agricultural inputs such as seeds, fertilizers, animal feed, small equipment, and the requisite training necessary for boosting agricultural production. This strategic input has paved the way for increased food availability, significantly contributing towards self-sufficiency and reducing dependency on food aid. Additionally, the project also focused on improving livestock health, which is vital for the livelihoods of vulnerable households. It achieved this by vaccinating and treating approximately 11,700 animals owned by these households against common diseases, preventing morbidity and mortality, and thus safeguarding their living means. These interventions, comprehensive in nature, have led to the production of about 80,000 tons of food for both personal consumption and market selling, showcasing a substantial impact in addressing food scarcity, improving livelihoods, and enhancing resilience against future crises.
implementer: Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development

project: Türkiye Climate Resilient Forests Project
description: This use case example outlines efforts to strengthen institutions and society for wildfire and forest resilience through comprehensive review and strategy development. In the context of addressing the increasing risk of wildfires in Türkiye, particularly influenced by climate change, the project focused on enhancing the effectiveness of managing and protecting the country’s forests. This involved a meticulous review of existing legislation, regulations, and policy frameworks to identify gaps and needs arising from emerging wildfire risks. The project undertook a detailed analysis of various institutional frameworks, including Forest Law, various circulars and regulations related to forest fires, and the National Forest Fires Intervention Plan. Aimed at strengthening the policy, legal, and institutional frameworks, the initiative considered factors unique to Türkiye, such as social structure, forest situations, climate change impacts, and more. By drawing from international best practices and comprehensive stakeholders' engagement, draft revisions were proposed to address identified gaps, alongside the preparation of a National Integrated Fire Management Strategy and updating strategic plans. This multifaceted approach showcases a strategic method of bolstering wildfire resilience through institutional strengthening and strategic planning.

project: Türkiye Climate Resilient Forests Project
description: This use case example details the enhancement of fire cause investigation capabilities in Türkiye to address the high rate of 'unknown' fire ignitions. Understanding fire causes is critical for reducing ignition risk, which is intrinsically linked to the sources, agents, and motivations behind approximately 90% of fires. The project embarked on strengthening fire investigation capabilities to support ignition risk reduction strategies. This involved a comprehensive review and analysis of laws, regulations, and current practices of fire investigation in Türkiye, alongside examining successful examples globally. Knowledge exchange on Fire Cause Investigation, including participation in international trainings and engaging with other countries, formed a vital part of this initiative. Stakeholders' consultation was conducted to outline roles, responsibilities, and collaboration for effective fire management. The result was the development of a guide and training materials on fire investigation for fire management professionals in Türkiye, ultimately aiming to significantly reduce the proportion of fires with unknown causes and enhance wildfire prevention efforts.
implementer: Directorate General of Forestry (OGM)

project: Türkiye Climate Resilient Forests Project
description: This use case example emphasizes the importance of maintaining and improving the forest road network to enhance access for wildfire management in Türkiye, particularly in the wake of the destructive 2021 wildfires. The project recognized the critical role of road access for transportation during fire emergencies, which highlighted the need for a well-maintained and accessible road network. To address this, the project increased the purchase of machinery, such as bulldozers and graders, primarily for supporting the maintenance of the forest road network. This initiative focused on ensuring accessibility during the fire season and keeping roads open, including fire watchtower roads and fire safety roads used for transportation during fires. Additionally, the machinery could be utilized to maintain, repair, and open new road access in case of wildfires and help rehabilitate forest roads destroyed by other disasters. This approach underscores the essential link between road maintenance and effective wildfire response and recovery efforts.

project: Türkiye Climate Resilient Forests Project
description: This use case example explores the engagement of local communities and stakeholders in wildfire risk reduction activities through training and awareness raising in Türkiye. Acknowledging that local communities possess essential knowledge about fire ignitions, risks, and rapid response options, the project emphasized the importance of incorporating local participation in fire management. The initiative involved engaging with local leaders to understand each selected forest village's wildfire risk context, needs, and interests. Agreements and consultations were established to educate and train forest villagers on fire preparedness, including fire danger analysis, fire behavior principles, and evacuation strategies. Capacity-building activities included training on the Incident Command System (ICS), fire suppression priorities, and safety principles. Moreover, the project addressed gender aspects by aiming to enhance women's access to knowledge and skills for economic activity development in the forest sector. Ultimately, the project exemplified a participatory approach to wildfire management, leveraging local knowledge and community involvement to enhance wildfire preparedness and resilience.

project: PROGREEN Kazakhstan Resilient Landscapes Restoration Project
description: This use case example presents a method to pilot agroforestry practices using a community-centered approach. In the context of Kazakhstan's efforts to diversify its economy and enhance the sustainability of its land and forests, the 'PROGREEN Kazakhstan Resilient Landscapes Restoration Project' undertakes an innovative approach to land restoration and biodiversity conservation. Faced with significant environmental challenges such as desertification, land degradation, and the need for economic diversification particularly in the agriculture sector, the project aims to improve agricultural productivity, land health, and community livelihoods through agroforestry practices. By piloting these practices on territories adjacent to protected areas, the initiative targets to demonstrate the feasibility and benefits of integrating trees and shrubs into agricultural landscapes. This endeavor supports the broader government's goal of increasing forest cover and combating climate change impacts. The activities encompass engaging local communities and selected farms, granting them the means to implement these practices effectively. Collectively, this pilot aims to preserve the unique plant collections and contribute to the region's ecological and agricultural resilience.
implementer: Forestry and Wildlife Committee of the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources

project: PROGREEN Kazakhstan Resilient Landscapes Restoration Project
description: This use case example showcases a method for enhancing government capacity for the management of protected areas using an integrated landscape approach. Deployed in the realm of the 'PROGREEN Kazakhstan Resilient Landscapes Restoration Project,' this method addresses the urgent need for ecological conservation amidst Kazakhstan's rich but vulnerable landscapes, including its small proportion of forested areas prone to desertification and degradation. The context of enhancing capacities encompasses both physical infrastructure improvements and knowledge enhancement among forestry organizations within South Kazakhstan's Aksu Zhabagly and Karatau State Natural Reserves. These reserves, celebrated for their biodiversity and inclusion within UNESCO Biosphere Reserves, require focused conservation efforts. Through improved eco-tourism elements, biodiversity monitoring, and the reinforcement of forestry organizations, the project seeks to advance environmental rehabilitation and preservation objectives. The commitment also includes nurturing the unique plant collections and revitalizing the arboretum at the Kazakh Scientific Research Institute of Forestry. By embedding an integrated landscape approach, the project aspires to bolster biodiversity conservation while fostering sustainable economic opportunities through eco-tourism.
implementer: Forestry and Wildlife Committee of the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources

project: Morocco Climate Operation / Support to the Nationally-Determined Contribution (NDC)
description: This use case example demonstrates the integration of a 'Whole of Government' approach to address climate change. In the context of Moroccan development, the project recognized the multifaceted challenges posed by climate change that cannot be resolved through sectoral lenses alone. The Kingdom of Morocco took a coordinated policy-making approach that systematically incorporated climate considerations, aligning with the 'Helsinki Principles'. The strategy encompasses fiscal planning, budgeting, public investment management, and procurement practices to expedite the transition towards a low-carbon and climate-resilient economy. Moreover, this approach emphasized the importance of a robust and reliable climate information system to support effective climate actions and policies. By leveraging fiscal and policy instruments and enhancing the climate data system, this use case explores how a comprehensive government-wide effort can significantly impact developing a climate-informed development path, pushing the nation towards resilience and sustainability.

project: Morocco Climate Operation / Support to the Nationally-Determined Contribution (NDC)
description: This use case example highlights the project's strategies to enhance resilience and inclusion in vulnerable rural areas amidst climate threats. Within the context of Moroccan rural communities, which often comprise populations living below the poverty line and relying on climate-sensitive activities such as rainfed agriculture, the project identified priority areas based on extensive analytical work. Initiatives such as the 'Solidarity Agriculture' program, the rollout of a new social protection system, and the expansion of agriculture insurance schemes for small farmers were implemented. Additionally, innovation in agriculture through genetic improvement of seeds, R&D on no-tillage practices, and extension services were introduced. The project also focused on the rehabilitation of oases and forest programs for watershed protection and forest fire management. By centering efforts on supporting vulnerable farmers and agricultural workers, innovating in agriculture, and enhancing ecosystem resilience, this use case illustrates comprehensive strategies for fostering resilience and inclusion in rural, climate-sensitive regions.
implementer: Caisse Nationale de Securité Sociale, Agence pour le Développement Agricole, Ministère de la Transition Energétique et du Développement Durable (MTEDD), Agence Nationale des Eaux et Forêts (ANEF), Ministère de l'Agriculture, de la Pêche Maritime, du Développement Rural et des Eaux et Forêts, Direction Générale de la Météorologie (DGM), Ministry of Economy and Finance, Ministère de l’Équipement et de l’Eau (MEE), Agence Nationale de Développement des Zones Oasiennes et Arganier (ANDZOA)

title: Enhancing Rural Resilience and Inclusion

project: Methane-Reducing and Water-Saving Paddy Rice Program for Results (Hunan)
description: This use case example demonstrates the targeted intervention in rice production via specialized sub-plans under a broader agricultural project. In the context of China's vast agricultural landscape, the High-Standard Farmland Construction Program (HSFCP) encompasses the entire mainland, focusing on rice, wheat, and maize. Specifically, the HSFCP-Rice sub-plan addresses the unique needs of the main rice-producing provinces by categorizing rice production systems based on regional differences in climate and soil conditions—ranging from one rice crop in the Northeast to two to three crops in warmer regions. The initiative is characterized by its comprehensive approach that mirrors the broader HSFCP objectives, emphasizing climate-adapted cultivation strategies, efficient water use, and sustainable farming practices to enhance quality and yield. An important aspect of this project is its significant budget allocation, constituting about one-third of the overall HSFCP funds, indicative of the significant priority placed on rice production within China's agricultural sector.
implementer: Hunan Provincial Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs

title: Enhanced Rice Production

project: Methane-Reducing and Water-Saving Paddy Rice Program for Results (Hunan)
description: This use case example illustrates an integrated approach to promoting green and resilient paddy production while managing environmental and social risks. Set in the backdrop of China's National High-Standard Farmland Construction Plan (2021-2030), the program aims to support a subset of activities, ranging from policy reforms, irrigation and water management improvements, nutrient management, to institutional strengthening. Notably, interventions like the adoption of smart irrigation technologies, soil testing, and fertilizer optimization strategies typify efforts to reduce reliance on chemicals, thus contributing to environmental sustainability. The program's design is cautious of environmental and social risks, excluding activities with potential adverse impacts, such as large-scale infrastructure projects that may exacerbate water scarcity. Through such exclusions and the inclusion of beneficial practices, the program works towards achieving significant positive environmental and social outcomes in participating regions, effectively balancing agricultural productivity with ecosystem health and community welfare.
implementer: Hunan Provincial Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs

title: Environmental and Social Enhancement

project: Agriculture Governance, Growth and Resilience Investment Project
description: This use case example details the process of enhancing sector governance and agriculture knowledge management to improve policy formulation, public spending monitoring, and evaluation in the agriculture sector. In the context of the Agriculture Governance Growth and Resilience Investment Project, key institutions were digitalized, and service delivery in food quality and safety was enhanced. Efforts focused on supporting the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Irrigation (MAFI) extension services, modernizing veterinary services, and strengthening linkages between business service providers and farmers. A notable initiative included upgrading the functionality of the Agency for Interventions and Payments in Agriculture (AIPA), involving technical assistance for aligning with EU fiduciary requirements, staffing reforms, technical upgrades, and digitalization efforts. Another critical sub-component was improving food safety systems, which aimed to build human, institutional, and technical capacities for food quality and safety management, aligning with EU standards. Activities encompassed regulatory support for harmonizing national frameworks with EU requirements, institutional capacity building, and technical enhancements to food safety management institutions.
implementer: Ministry of Agriculture and Food Industry

title: Enhancing Sector Governance

project: Agriculture Governance, Growth and Resilience Investment Project
description: This use case example showcases the efforts to enhance access to agricultural knowledge among Moldovan farmers, aiming to bolster their competitiveness and ensure effective absorption of public and EU funds. In the context of fragmented and inefficient knowledge management systems, the initiative prioritized modernizing advisory services, incorporating gender-inclusive approaches, and offering customized services. The establishment of the Agricultural and Rural Advisory Center (ARAC) as the apex institution for providing consolidated advisory services was a significant step. This move was supplemented by legislative reviews, coaching programs, the development of digital tools, and the creation of an agricultural market information system. Efforts aimed to decentralize knowledge management and advisory service delivery to improve access to essential knowledge through web and mobile applications, online courses, and kiosks. A focus on climate resilience, including promoting climate-smart technologies and farming practices, was integral to revamping advisory services effectively.
implementer: Ministry of Agriculture and Food Industry

title: Agricultural Knowledge Enhancement

project: Tanzania Food Systems Resilience Program
description: This use case example demonstrates the approach of strengthening delivery systems in agricultural research, extension, and seed dissemination. In the context of the Tanzania Food Systems Resilience Program, a multi-phase endeavor aimed at enhancing food system resilience across Eastern and Southern Africa, Phase 2 has been specifically dedicated to supporting resilience by boosting agricultural service delivery alongside the adoption of climate-resilient technologies and better fiscal performance within the agricultural sector. The program allocates US$300 million towards these objectives, with a significant focus on improving service delivery mechanisms. The operation delineates three key result areas, the first of which emphasizes refining the systems in place for agricultural research, extension services, and seed distribution through interventions such as developing sustainable financing mechanisms for climate-resilient agricultural technologies, enhancing extension outreach with Information and Communication Technology (ICT) solutions for promoting climate-smart practices, and strengthening the seed value chain. The initiative not only aims at expanding the reach of agricultural services but also at ensuring these services are effectively aligned with the needs of modern agriculture, particularly under the increasing threat of climate change.
implementer: Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation, Natural Resources and Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture

title: Strengthening Delivery Systems

project: Tanzania Food Systems Resilience Program
description: This use case example focuses on developing resilient rural agricultural infrastructure to support food systems resilience. Within the scope of the Tanzania Food Systems Resilience Program, a substantial element pertains to the improvement of infrastructure critical to agricultural productivity and sustainability. The program, being part of a larger, multi-phase effort spanning several countries in Eastern and Southern Africa, dedicates a portion of its US$300 million budget to this endeavor. Key interventions under this initiative include the introduction and implementation of performance-based Operations Management and Maintenance (OMM) contracts for infrastructure projects, the effective management of public warehouse facilities to improve storage capacity and reduce post-harvest losses, and the comprehensive assessment and scaling up of soil health management practices. These strategic emphases are designed to bolster the resilience of rural infrastructures against environmental stresses, thereby ensuring a more reliable and climate-adaptive agricultural framework. By facilitating more robust and sustainable structures, the program aims to foster a conducive environment for the delivery of critical agricultural services and enhance the overall productivity of the sector.
implementer: Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation, Natural Resources and Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture

title: Developing Resilient Rural Infrastructure

project: Tanzania Food Systems Resilience Program
description: This use case example represents the method of strengthening fiscal performance within the agricultural sector to enable priority investments, as part of the Tanzania Food Systems Resilience Program. In addressing the challenges associated with food system resilience, the program underscores the importance of enhancing fiscal management and governance in agriculture. With a total operation budget of US$300 million, the program's third key result area focuses on improving fiscal performance by implementing strategies such as improving budget monitoring and predictability in agriculture, thereby ensuring more efficient and effective use of resources. The initiative also involves scaling up financial support for the development and dissemination of climate-resilient technologies, which is critical for adapting to the rapidly changing climatic conditions that impact agricultural productivity. Through these efforts, the program seeks to establish a stronger financial foundation for the agricultural sector, enabling it to better support the delivery of essential services and invest in priority areas such as climate resilience, infrastructure development, and innovative agricultural technologies.

title: Strengthening Fiscal Performance

project: Philippine Fisheries and Coastal Resiliency Project
description: This use case example illustrates the development and implementation of Fisheries and Coastal Resilient Resource Planning & Management within a developing nation's coastal regions. In the context of aiming for an ecosystem approach to fisheries management, the project team embarked on creating comprehensive planning frameworks and institutional arrangements. These plans included overarching Fisheries Management Area (FMA) Framework Plans, targeted fisheries management plans, aquaculture development, and marine habitat management and restoration plans. The endeavor focused on establishing the necessary capacity, regulatory frameworks, and management measures to ensure the sustainable exploitation and conservation of marine resources. It specifically targeted the development of plans that would pave the way for holistic ecosystem preservation, thus ensuring that fisheries management efforts are sustainable, inclusive, and contribute to the resilience of coastal communities against environmental changes.
implementer: Department of Agriculture - Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources

title: Coastal Resilience Planning

project: Philippine Fisheries and Coastal Resiliency Project
description: This use case example involves the development and establishment of environmental and socio-economic baselines for monitoring fisheries and marine habitats. In the context of elevating conservation efforts within specific Fisheries Management Areas (FMAs), the project team initiated the design, piloting, and establishment of survey systems aimed at gathering crucial baseline data. The approach sought to refine existing survey systems by incorporating municipal fisheries into the catch and effort statistics for each FMA, thereby ensuring a more comprehensive monitoring framework. By enhancing the accuracy and scope of baseline data, the initiative laid a foundational step towards effective management and conservation strategies, aimed at sustaining ecological balance and supporting the socio-economic wellbeing of coastal communities.

project: Philippine Fisheries and Coastal Resiliency Project
description: This use case example discusses the implementation of a comprehensive communication and education strategy aimed at promoting understanding and support for fisheries management plans and conservation measures among key stakeholders. In the context of widespread community engagement and participation in Fisheries Management Area (FMA) initiatives, the method emphasized the creation and execution of annual communication and education campaigns. It included leveraging different local languages, establishing a data-driven project website, and engaging stakeholders through social media. This multidimensional approach effectively built community awareness and endorsement of new fishing controls, sanctions for non-compliance, and available livelihood support systems, thereby fostering a collaborative and informed stakeholder base for sustainable fisheries management.

title: Communication and Education

project: Philippine Fisheries and Coastal Resiliency Project
description: This use case example explores the execution of Marine Habitat Management and Restoration Plans (MHMRPs) within designated coastal zones. In the context of comprehensive Coastal Resource Management (CRM) efforts, the project paid special attention to the establishment of community-led management regimes for littoral and near-shore habitats. These regimes invited community participation in return for instituting sustainable management systems, complemented by initiatives such as beach clean-up, mangrove and coral reef rehabilitation, and restocking efforts. This method not only aimed at preserving critical habitats but also at empowering local communities through capacity building, technical assistance, and the implementation of sustainable management practices, thus fostering both ecological conservation and community resilience.

project: Philippine Fisheries and Coastal Resiliency Project
description: This use case example focuses on enhancing the aquaculture and fisheries sectors through catalytic investments in enterprise development, technical, marketing support, and critical public infrastructure. In the context of bolstering productive, resilient, and effective fisheries and aquaculture value chains, the project team provided technical assistance for enterprise formation, market information platforms, promotional activities, and support for online trading. Furthermore, infrastructure investments supported climate-resilient fisheries, research and regulatory facilities, and commercial service facilities. This multifaceted approach aimed to improve market access, introduce innovative technologies, and facilitate sustainable enterprise growth within fisheries and aquaculture, thus contributing to economic development and environmental sustainability in coastal regions.

Srimathi Sridhar: Hello everyone, and welcome
back to The Development Podcast from the World Bank. I'm Srimathi Sridhar, coming to you from Washington,
DC. This is the first of some very special episodes
we've got for you here, where we're exploring how to end poverty on a livable planet, and
what a livable planet really means. Today, we'll be turning our attention to climate
change. And as I speak to you, the 28th UN Climate
Summit, or COP28, is already underway. The focus there is on cutting emissions, adaptation,
and solutions that can address the challenges of a world that is warming far too quickly. We'll hear about the urgent need for climate
action from the Prime Minister of the Pacific Island Nation of Samoa. Fiamē Naomi Mata'Afa: We know what the challenge
is. We know the targets that we need to reach
if we are to survive. Srimathi Sridhar: From youth activists urging
the international community to ensure a livable planet for their future. Brianna Fruean: I felt like I was blessed
to grow up in paradise, and a very big problem that I felt was about to take away this paradise
for me was climate change. Srimathi Sridhar: We'll get the big picture
from the UN. Inger Andersen: If we look at 10% of the highest
income population, they are responsible for 48% of all emissions. The bottom 50% of the world population, they
are responsible for just 12% of emissions.

Climate change increases instability, conflict,
hunger and threatens lives, livelihoods and biodiversity. It also disproportionately impacts the world's
poor. For young people, especially those in parts
of the world where climate change has a very visceral effect, the crisis is something they
have grown up with, and many as our producer, Sarah Treanor found out, are using their voice
to call for action. Sarah Treanor: Pacific Island nations have
been at the sharp edge of climate change for years, with rising sea levels, extreme weather
and coastal erosion, to name but a few of the urgent challenges facing this group of
small countries. For many young people, job prospects too have
been impacted by the climate crisis. So, I spoke to one young activist who has
been raising her voice on the issues facing her home country of Samoa since she was a
small child. Brianna Fruean: [foreign language]. My name is [foreign language] Brianna Fruean. So, [foreign language] is my Samoan chiefly
name, and I do climate work. Sarah Treanor: I asked Brianna to describe
to me a sense of what it was like growing up. Brianna Fruean: Picture perfect, picturesque,
clear waters, white sandy beaches, type beach you see in a postcard. I was always surrounded by waterfalls and
lush gardens and forests growing up.

From these small little things like the visual
change of fish stock to the big things like the cyclone and actually physically being
in a cyclone, being in two and three cyclones from the age of 10 to the age of 15. And I would talk to my mom. She said that her first cyclone she experienced
was when she was 19, and so I started to physically and emotionally encapsulate what climate change
was because I realized that I was living in it. Sarah Treanor: And is there an event you can
recall, Brianna, where it really all started to seem very urgent? Brianna Fruean: I think the first shift of
land that I really had to deal with, or be a part of a conversation around it, was the
shift in grave sites. So in Samoa, we believe that those who have
passed on should be laid to rest with the best views. And so, a lot of our villages, we bury our
ancestors near the ocean so that they have a view of the ocean. And then, I started hearing conversations
in my family and my community of moving grave sites because the ocean was coming closer
and closer and cracking the concrete of the graveyards. And that was the first shock to my system
and the injustice for Samoan and Samoan family, to have to dig up their dead and move them
and wake them from their rest.

Srimathi Sridhar: Thanks to Brianna and Sarah. Well, let's stay in this part of the world

of the smallest economic zones because of our geographical placing. We're sort of like in the middle of the Pacific
Ocean. If there's a significant impact of climate
change for our people here, the more immediate ones of course is the experience because most
of our villages are coastal. It's very immediate. The other immediate impact, and I suppose
this is also part of the development processes, the clearing of land, especially going upland
where there is water catchment areas. There's the erosion then from the inline side
where there's been encroachment on water catchment areas. So, it's a mix of climate change and development
progress. The economies of small island states, they're
really always on a back foot. So, to make that progress is very difficult. So perhaps, I could say, in the last 30 years
since the early '90s, we've had about five major incidences in Samoa, related to climate
change.

The United Nations Environment program, UNEP,
plays a critical role in discussions around climate, nature and pollution. And I wanted to speak to them about how we
can end poverty on a livable planet. But first, let's hear from another activist,
this time in West Africa. Kenny McCarthy: My name is Kenny McCarthy. I live in Accra, Ghana. I am most concerned by the lack of concern
for the climate crisis in general. So, for example, in Accra, Ghana, when I was
growing up and when I was a child, if I wanted to drink a bottle of Coke, I would be sent
to the store with a basket and a napkin, and that's how we bought our stuff. And somewhere along the line, plastic bags
were introduced, and now the entire city is littered. Our gutters are choked with plastic. There's plastic in our grounds. It's everywhere. And the same way we chose as individuals to
change to plastic bags to cause the problem, we can switch back to tote bags and reusable
bags to become the solution in some way to this problem. So, a livable planet is one that has clean
water, is one that has adequate temperatures for different species, different plants, different
animals to grow and to live a good quality

we can switch back to tote bags and reusable
bags to become the solution in some way to this problem. So, a livable planet is one that has clean
water, is one that has adequate temperatures for different species, different plants, different
animals to grow and to live a good quality of life. Srimathi Sridhar: So, let's get to the scale
of the challenge for the global community. Inger Andersen, Executive Director of the
United Nations Environment Program, join me from Nairobi. I began by asking her to paint a picture of
the threats to the planet. Inger Andersen: We speak about this sort of
triple planetary crisis, right? These are the underlying threats to stability
of planet earth as we know it. First, crisis, obviously the climate crisis. I think everybody understands that. And look, if you look at the numbers, 86 days
recorded with super hot temperatures just this past year, the hottest September on record,
and we are already at 1.8 degrees above pre-industrial levels. So, we are not in a good place. So, I think people get the climate crisis. The second crisis we speak about is the nature
and biodiversity loss crisis. Maybe less known and less understood because
people don't see it immediately before their
summary: A video on the World Bank's YouTube channel detailing the impact of the climate crisis and urgent solutions to address it, featuring voices from Samoa, UNEP, and the World Bank. #climatecrisis #climatechange

excerpt:
So, we are not in a good place. So, I think people get the climate crisis. The second crisis we speak about is the nature
and biodiversity loss crisis. Maybe less known and less understood because
people don't see it immediately before their eyes. But 1 million species of the nearly 8 million
on this planet are threatened by overuse, by fragmentation, by climate change, by chemicals,
and so on. And that obviously is quite concerning. And then, when we look at ecosystem loss,
like 10 football pitches a minute, loss of tropical primary forest and so on, these are
real issues. So, that's a nature loss crisis. And lastly, we speak about the pollution and
waste crisis, that toxic trail of our own civilization. Now, we need to have jobs and industry and
economy to keep the wheels turning, but we cannot afford to do that while we thrash our
planet. Srimathi Sridhar: And I think this is a good
segue to UNEP's Emissions Gap Report. I'm seeing here that the report looks at where
greenhouse gas emissions are predicted to be in 2030, versus where they actually should
be to avert some of the worst impacts of climate change. So, can you tell me more about this year's
report and how far off track are we?

excerpt:
I'm seeing here that the report looks at where
greenhouse gas emissions are predicted to be in 2030, versus where they actually should
be to avert some of the worst impacts of climate change. So, can you tell me more about this year's
report and how far off track are we? Inger Andersen: Yeah. So, the report is a sober read, a read that
comes out and we always issue it immediately prior to the COP. And exactly as you say, it measures that gap,
right, between where we are and where we should be. And we can now say that we are looking at
an emission of 57.4 gigatons of CO2 in 2022, and that that's an increase between '21 and
'22, an increase of 1.2%. So, that's a worry. And when we look at the G20, who together
are responsible for 76% of all emissions, let me say that again. 20 countries are responsible for 76% of emissions. So that's an important point that I always
try to emphasize. When we look at that and we see that G20 countries
who have that responsibility to reduce have actually increased, that's a concern. And so, that's not the way we want to go. The current policies that we have, those policies,
this is the Emissions Gap Report, the current
summary: A video on the World Bank's YouTube channel detailing the impact of the climate crisis and urgent solutions to address it, featuring voices from Samoa, UNEP, and the World Bank. #climatecrisis #climatechange
title: Tackling the Climate Crisis 🎙️ The Development Podcast

excerpt:
When we look at that and we see that G20 countries
who have that responsibility to reduce have actually increased, that's a concern. And so, that's not the way we want to go. The current policies that we have, those policies,
this is the Emissions Gap Report, the current policies that are in place will take us to
three degrees warming by 2100. If we take the unconditional NDCs, which are
those that countries have promised what they will do, it will take us to 2.9 degrees. So, it only shaves 0.1 degree off. If we then say the conditional NDCs, I.e.,
if there is money, we will also, it takes us to 2.5 degrees in 2100. None of the above are acceptable, none of
the above. Which then means that the stock take will
have to therefore mean that all countries, but especially the G20 will have the biggest
emissions load, will have to really, really stretch. And that's what we need to see by, if we want
to hit the 1.5, which last year we called the report the closing window, we have to
cut emissions by nearly 50%, by 42% by 2030. If we want to hit two degrees, which we really
don't, we have to cut it by 28%, not increase. I mean, we keep calling out the G20 because
that is where we have this 76% of all emissions. But there's also huge injustice, right? Because if we look at 10% of the highest income
population, they are responsible for 48% of

Inger Andersen: Back in the late '70s, scientists
came out, and actually told us, "There's a hole in the ozone layer on both sides of the
pole. This is not a good thing. It's going to have all these impacts that
we need to understand." And the world came together and said, "Okay,
let's do a treaty around this. Let's do what is known today as a Vienna convention
and a Montreal Protocol." Industry at the time said, "Can't be done. You can't cool things without HCFCs. We need these chemicals. You want to refrigerate your food, this is
the only way." The world said, "Well, anyway, we are doing
it." And guess what? Industry came up with amazing solutions. Today, the ozone layer is healing. Similarly, I could mention, just was it two
years ago, UNEP has been having a long campaign to exit lead from petrol, and now there is
no more. So, these things happen. So, we have shown again and again that we
can succeed. We have the Paris Accord. Now we need a global commitment to live up
to what we promised one another.

that we are about people and the planet, and

game changers for us? Anna Bjerde: There are quite a few of them,
but the ones that give me a real sense of hope, if I can put it that way, and I think
they're actually achievable and tangible, are on the mitigation side, definitely the
energy transition. By 2027, we anticipate that solar will surpass
coal as the most available source of energy. And I think that is because we have seen the
cost curve go down. We have seen countries around the world put
a bet on solar, and it's starting to show. But also, the energy transition has to come
with what we also call a just transition. As we phase out one old way of doing things
and introduce a new way of doing things, we need to make sure we don't leave anyone behind. As we might see some jobs drop off, we need
to make sure we're focusing on the creation of new jobs, which means re-skilling, engaging
populations that are affected often in areas that are quite concentrated with the old way
of doing things. If you think about a coal region, for example.

the World Bank is kind of doing in this area? Anna Bjerde: So, the needs for financing climate
action are huge, and there's many things that we need to do. First and foremost, we need to make sure that
we work both on reducing emissions, that's really the mitigation side. We also need to make sure that we work on
adaptation and building resilience because there are many countries around the world
that are really not emitting, but they're feeling the impact of climate change. So, we need to remember that we need to finance
the comprehensive set of challenges. But what it also means is that we need to
give good policy advice. One of the big sources of finance is actually
elimination of subsidies, and turning the subsidies.

So, we need to remember that we need to finance
the comprehensive set of challenges. But what it also means is that we need to
give good policy advice. One of the big sources of finance is actually
elimination of subsidies, and turning the subsidies. We estimate that there's more than $7 trillion
of annual environmentally harmful subsidies. Imagine if all of that, or even a portion
of that, a share of that, was able to be put forward to dealing with climate change. We could really use that. But it also means that what we are doing is
putting a renewed focus on the combination of public and private and partnerships with
the private sector, and I think this is so important. Srimathi Sridhar: I feel like I'd be remiss
if I didn't ask you about the World Bank's Country Climate Development Reports. I know that they're a very important tool. Can you explain to the audience why? Why is it so important, as we kind of look
at the climate crisis? Anna Bjerde: We have about 40 of them now,
and what they do is look at two very important points for our clients. One is, how do you achieve inclusive and sustainable
economic growth, which every country is trying to do, especially now when we have been in
a recovery mode from crisis after crisis.

excerpt:
Anna Bjerde: We have about 40 of them now,
and what they do is look at two very important points for our clients. One is, how do you achieve inclusive and sustainable
economic growth, which every country is trying to do, especially now when we have been in
a recovery mode from crisis after crisis. But how do you do it at the same time as you're
dealing with climate change? And many countries around the world wonder,
can you have economic growth and climate action at the same time? And these reports actually show, with very
robust analytics that yes, absolutely you can. And in fact, for many countries, not addressing

excerpt: Located in the heart of the Sahel,  Niger is a land of singular beauty, but it is also one of the countries most vulnerable to climate change. Recurrent droughts, unpredictable rainfall and flooding in some regions wreak havoc in the country.  The number of people struggling with food insecurity  was over 2 million in early 2023. Right now, climate change is affecting our lives  in so many ways.  When rain isn’t plentiful in the rainy season, we have to be very patient.  We sowed our seeds, then suddenly a drought came and dried up everything that had sprouted.  We then had to sow again. After that, the rains came.  The millet, corn, beans—everything we sowed —began to grow.  But by the end of the rainy season, the rain came down heavier and everything  we were hoping to harvest couldn’t ripen in all that rain.
summary: A video on the World Bank's YouTube channel detailing how the Sahel Adaptive Social Protection program is helping Niger fight food insecurity caused by climate change.
title: Répondre à la sècheresse au Niger : Programme de Protection Sociale Adaptative

excerpt: —began to grow.  But by the end of the rainy season, the rain came down heavier and everything  we were hoping to harvest couldn’t ripen in all that rain.   Through the Sahel Adaptive Social Protection Program,  thousands of families in Niger were able to diversify and increase their income, and become more resilient  to climate shocks through the cash transfers and different types of training they received.  After a disappointing 2021 rainy season,  the drought response component was activated,  , and over 15,000 families received emergency monthly transfers to offset poor harvests. The drought response pilot is now being rolled out  on a wider scale. If we look at annual rainfall historically,  the trend is toward more rain, meaning we are seeing rainier years than in the past.  That said, the question of when it rains is now the problem,  since the rains now come early
summary: A video on the World Bank's YouTube channel detailing how the Sahel Adaptive Social Protection program is helping Niger fight food insecurity caused by climate change.
title: Répondre à la sècheresse au Niger : Programme de Protection Sociale Adaptative

excerpt: the trend is toward more rain, meaning we are seeing rainier years than in the past.  That said, the question of when it rains is now the problem,  since the rains now come early  and we have considerably long dry spells.  This means the rainfall is not evenly distributed,  and that creates problems. So, we developed tools that provide us the data to help identify  where crops are planted depending on their growth cycle. I never used to be self-sufficient.  But now, with what I earn, I can buy corn.  We can now cook dambou (semolina) and the children can eat their fill.  With what I save, I have enough to buy food to eat.  My advice to everyone is don’t say I’m not going to work. Work makes you strong.  You have to invest where you know it will help you earn you money.  Because, now that I can manage to put aside some savings,  I’ve been able to buy a motor pump  and it does a good job of watering the crops.

excerpt: Over the past decade, the World Bank has been supporting the Philippine government in building the country's resilience in building the country's resilience to climate change and natural disasters. The Philippines is one of the most disaster-prone countries in the world. Over 70% of the population is exposed to multiple hazards, including climate-related shocks. All of us want a safe and resilient society.  Many countries struggle with (post-disaster) recovery. There are many challenges such as coordination with stakeholders,  funding sources and identification of priorities. With hard-earned lessons from past disasters, the country is advancing  its disaster risk management strategies. The government's proactive measures emphasize readiness and a swift response
summary: A video on the World Bank's YouTube channel detailing the Philippines' disaster risk management approach and the Ready to Rebuild program.
title: Strengthening Disaster and Climate Resilience in the Philippines

excerpt: the country is advancing  its disaster risk management strategies. The government's proactive measures emphasize readiness and a swift response focusing on infrastructure resilience, social safety nets, disaster risk financing, and capacity enhancement. Among the country's latest innovations is the PlanSmart Ready to Rebuild Program to ensure that Filipinos are empowered to respond to the aftermath of disasters. The PlanSmart App is a very innovative application,  where we can actually prepare to recover even before a disaster would happen. This would enable local government units, local chief executives for example or disaster managers, to have an imagination of what can happen in their area
summary: A video on the World Bank's YouTube channel detailing the Philippines' disaster risk management approach and the Ready to Rebuild program.
title: Strengthening Disaster and Climate Resilience in the Philippines

excerpt: local chief executives for example or disaster managers, to have an imagination of what can happen in their area based on exposure, hazards, and simulations so that they are able to really appreciate the impact of the events that can trigger disasters in the area. Our local government unit decided to  join the training program  because we want to explore the different available platforms that will help our city formulate plans efficiently and effectively.  Since it is faster to generate the information and data, the waiting time is shorter for those who need assistance from the LGU. The country is strengthening its resilience by building the capacity of national and local governments  on pre-disaster recovery preparedness. The World Bank continues to support the Philippines
summary: A video on the World Bank's YouTube channel detailing the Philippines' disaster risk management approach and the Ready to Rebuild program.
title: Strengthening Disaster and Climate Resilience in the Philippines

excerpt: The country is strengthening its resilience by building the capacity of national and local governments  on pre-disaster recovery preparedness. The World Bank continues to support the Philippines  in enhancing its capacity to prepare for, respond to, and recover from disasters.

that possible. It's that enabling environment that's key. Other lessons are that we need to constantly
be pushing on innovation. Our work with philanthropic partners, with commercial advisors and banks and other
partners like IDB and some of the Debt for Nature swaps we've
been doing have meant that I think we're really creating
a whole new market in that. It addresses the enormous over indebtedness
problem that many of the countries where we operate
face. But it's a use of our tool in a new and novel
way, our political risk insurance way, the political risk insurance tool, to make sure that we can complete these transactions. We want to see this market grow. It's important to have additional actors in
it, and it's important to partner as much as possible.

outlined for the International Development Association, were truly inspiring and have set a tone of
optimism and constructive engagement for the duration of the meeting. Dear Guests of honor, we are gathered here today for an event of
significant importance, the Mid-Term Review of the International Development
Association's 20th Replenishment, commonly known as IDA20 Mid-Term Review. This event marks a critical juncture in our
journey towards sustainable development and actualization of our collective inspiration
for economic growth and poverty reduction. IDA is a major resource of concessional resources
that are vital for countries that have few other means to fund their development. By providing these resources, IDA enables
developing countries to invest in areas that can have transformative impact on their
economies and population, ultimately contributing to poverty reduction
and sustainable development. Since its establishment, IDA has provided more than 530 billion U.S. dollars for investment
in over 115 countries. Given its strategic role, it is in most of
our developing economies.

excerpt:
To illustrate, IDA's 200 million U.S. dollars
support to our rural electrification program helped Tanzania to achieve one of the fastest
access expansion rates in Africa over the past decade. Though initially targeting 2.5 million people
since 2017, we have ensured access to electricity for
more than 4.5 million people, as well as rural hospitals and schools. This access has created employment and business
opportunities and improved outcomes for students in remote
areas. This program was so impactful that it attracted
additional fund financing of 335 million U.S. dollars to help realize even better outcomes for rural
communities. In the water sector in less than five years,
the 300 million U.S. dollar support package or the Sustainable Rural Water Supply and
Sanitation Program facilitated accessibility of water to over
4.7 million people, around half of whom are women. The program further improved access to sanitation
facilities for around 6.6 million people, 1,904 healthcare facilities, and 1,095 primary
schools. To ensure sustainability, this program supported the creation of the Rural Water Supply and
Sanitation Agency and strengthening of community-based water
supply organizations.
